scores.description: Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Temporal Score.
High - Functional autonomous code exists, exploit code works in every situation, and network-connected systems are likely to encounter exploitation attempts.
Functional - Functional exploit code is available. The code works in most situations where the vulnerability exists.
Proof of Concept - Proof-of-concept exploit code is available, or an attack demonstration is not practical for most systems.
Unproven - No exploit code is available, or an exploit is theoretical.
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Temporal Score.
Unavailable - There is either no solution available or it is impossible to apply.
Workaround - There is an unofficial, non-vendor solution available.
Temporary Fix - There is an official but temporary fix available. This includes instances where the vendor issues a temporary hotfix, tool, or workaround.
Official Fix - A complete vendor solution is available. Either the vendor has issued an official patch, or an upgrade is available.
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Temporal Score.
Confirmed - Source code is available to independently verify the assertions of the research, or the author or vendor of the affected code has confirmed the presence of the vulnerability.

Reasonable - Significant details are published, but researchers either do not have full confidence in the root cause, or do not have access to source code to fully confirm all of the interactions that may lead to the result.

Unknown - There are reports of impacts that indicate a vulnerability is present. The reports indicate that the cause of the vulnerability is unknown, or reports may differ on the cause or impacts of the vulnerability.
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Environmental Score.
High - Loss of Confidentiality is likely to have a catastrophic adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Medium - Loss of Confidentiality is likely to have a serious adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Low - Loss of Confidentiality is likely to have only a limited adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Environmental Score.
High - Loss of Integrity is likely to have a catastrophic adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Medium - Loss of Integrity is likely to have a serious adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Low - Loss of Integrity is likely to have only a limited adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Environmental Score.
High - Loss of Availability is likely to have a catastrophic adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Medium - Loss of Availability is likely to have a serious adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Low - Loss of Availability is likely to have only a limited adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Network - The vulnerable component is bound to the network stack and the set of possible attackers extends beyond the other options listed below, up to and including the entire Internet.
Adjacent - The vulnerable component is bound to the network stack, but the attack is limited at the protocol level to a logically adjacent topology.
Local - The vulnerable component is not bound to the network stack and the attacker’s path is via read/write/execute capabilities.
Physical - The attack requires the attacker to physically touch or manipulate the vulnerable component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Low - Specialized access conditions or extenuating circumstances do not exist. An attacker can expect repeatable success when attacking the vulnerable component.
High - A successful attack depends on conditions beyond the attacker's control.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
None - The attacker is unauthorized prior to attack, and therefore does not require any access to settings or files of the vulnerable system to carry out an attack.
Low - The attacker requires privileges that provide basic user capabilities that could normally affect only settings and files owned by a user.
High - The attacker requires privileges that provide significant (e.g., administrative) control over the vulnerable component allowing access to component-wide settings and files.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
None - The vulnerable system can be exploited without interaction from any user.
Required - Successful exploitation of this vulnerability requires a user to take some action before the vulnerability can be exploited.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Unchanged - An exploited vulnerability can only affect resources managed by the same security authority.
Changed - An exploited vulnerability can affect resources beyond the security scope managed by the security authority of the vulnerable component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of confidentiality, resulting in all resources within the impacted component being divulged to the attacker.

Low - There is some loss of confidentiality. Access to some restricted information is obtained, but the attacker does not have control over what information is obtained, or the amount or kind of loss is limited.
None - There is no loss of confidentiality within the impacted component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of integrity, or a complete loss of protection.
Low - Modification of data is possible, but the attacker does not have control over the consequence of a modification, or the amount of modification is limited.
None - There is no loss of integrity within the impacted component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of availability, resulting in the attacker being able to fully deny access to resources in the impacted component; this loss is either sustained or persistent.
Low - Performance is reduced or there are interruptions in resource availability.
None - There is no impact to availability within the impacted component.
Not Defined - Assigning this value indicates there is insufficient information to choose one of the other values, and has no impact on the overall Environmental Score.
High - Loss of Availability is likely to have a catastrophic adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Medium - Loss of Availability is likely to have a serious adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Low - Loss of Availability is likely to have only a limited adverse effect on the organization or individuals associated with the organization (e.g., employees, customers).
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Network - The vulnerable component is bound to the network stack and the set of possible attackers extends beyond the other options listed below, up to and including the entire Internet.
Adjacent - The vulnerable component is bound to the network stack, but the attack is limited at the protocol level to a logically adjacent topology.
Local - The vulnerable component is not bound to the network stack and the attacker’s path is via read/write/execute capabilities.
Physical - The attack requires the attacker to physically touch or manipulate the vulnerable component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Low - Specialized access conditions or extenuating circumstances do not exist. An attacker can expect repeatable success when attacking the vulnerable component.
High - A successful attack depends on conditions beyond the attacker's control.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
None - The attacker is unauthorized prior to attack, and therefore does not require any access to settings or files of the vulnerable system to carry out an attack.
Low - The attacker requires privileges that provide basic user capabilities that could normally affect only settings and files owned by a user.
High - The attacker requires privileges that provide significant (e.g., administrative) control over the vulnerable component allowing access to component-wide settings and files.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
None - The vulnerable system can be exploited without interaction from any user.
Required - Successful exploitation of this vulnerability requires a user to take some action before the vulnerability can be exploited.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
Unchanged - An exploited vulnerability can only affect resources managed by the same security authority.
Changed - An exploited vulnerability can affect resources beyond the security scope managed by the security authority of the vulnerable component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of confidentiality, resulting in all resources within the impacted component being divulged to the attacker.

Low - There is some loss of confidentiality. Access to some restricted information is obtained, but the attacker does not have control over what information is obtained, or the amount or kind of loss is limited.
None - There is no loss of confidentiality within the impacted component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of integrity, or a complete loss of protection.
Low - Modification of data is possible, but the attacker does not have control over the consequence of a modification, or the amount of modification is limited.
None - There is no loss of integrity within the impacted component.
Not Defined - Replaced with corresponding base score metric.
High - There is a total loss of availability, resulting in the attacker being able to fully deny access to resources in the impacted component; this loss is either sustained or persistent.
Low - Performance is reduced or there are interruptions in resource availability.
None - There is no impact to availability within the impacted component.
None - There is no technical impact to the software being analyzed at all.
Low - Minimal control over the software being analyzed.
Medium - Moderate control over the software being analyzed.
High - Significant control over the software being analyzed.
Critical - Complete control over the software being analyzed.
Default
NA - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
None - The attacker cannot gain access to any extra privileges.
Limited/Guest - The attacker gains access to an entity with limited or "guest" privileges.
Regular User - The attacker gains access to an entity that is a regular user who has no special privileges.
Partially-Privileged User - The attacker gains access to an entity with some special privileges.
Administrator - The attacker gains access to an entity with administrator, root, SYSTEM, or equivalent privileges.
Default
NA - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Network - The attacker gains access to an entity that is a regular user who has no special privileges.
System - The attacker gains access to an entity with some special privileges.
Application - The attacker gains access to an entity with administrator, root, SYSTEM, or equivalent privileges.
Enterprise - The attacker acquires privileges to a critical piece of enterprise infrastructure.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
None - No controls exist.
Limited - There are simplistic methods or accidental restrictions.
Moderate - The protection mechanism is commonly used but has known limitations.
Indirect (Defense-in-Depth) - The control does not specifically protect against exploitation of the weakness.
Best-Available - The control follows best current practices.
Complete - The control is completely effective against the weakness.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Proven False - The finding is erroneous.
Proven Locally True - The weakness occurs within an individual function or component.
Proven True - The control does not specifically protect against exploitation of the weakness.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Administrator - The entity has administrator, root, SYSTEM, or equivalent privileges.
Partially-Privileged User - The entity is a valid user with some special privileges.
Regular User - The entity is a regular user who has no special privileges.
Limited/Guest - The entity has limited or "guest" privileges that can significantly restrict allowed activities.
None - No privileges are required.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Network - The attacker must have privileges to access the network.
System - The attacker must have privileges to the underlying system or physical host that is being used to run the software under analysis.
Application - The attacker must have privileges that are supported within the software under analysis itself.
Enterprise Infrastructure - The attacker must have privileges on a critical piece of enterprise infrastructure.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Physical - The attacker must have physical access to the system that the software runs on
Local - The attacker must have an interactive, local (shell) account that interfaces directly with the underlying operating system.
Adjacent Network - An attacker must have access to a physical interface to the network.
Private Network - An attacker must have access to a private network.
Intranet - An attacker must have access to an enterprise intranet that is shielded from direct access from the Internet.
Internet - An attacker must have access to the Internet to reach the weakness.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Strong - The weakness requires strongest-available methods to tie the entity to a real-world identity.
Moderate - The weakness requires authentication using moderately strong methods.
Weak - The weakness requires a simple, weak authentication method that is easily compromised.
None - The weakness does not require any authentication at all.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
No Interaction - There is no interaction possible.
High - A large amount of social engineering is required.
Opportunistic - The attacker cannot directly control or influence the victim.
Moderate - The attacker must convince the user to perform an action that might appear suspicious.
Typical/Limited - The attacker must convince the user to perform an action that is common or regarded as "normal".
Automated - No human interaction is required.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Potentially Reachable - Potentially reachable**, but all code paths are currently safe.
Rare - Only present in rare platforms or configurations
Moderate - Present in common platforms or configurations
All - Present in all platforms or configurations
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
None - No impact.
Low - Minimal impact on the business/mission.
Medium - The business/mission would be affected, but without extensive damage to regular operations.
High - The operations of the business/mission would be significantly affected.
Critical - The business/mission could fail.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Low - An attacker is unlikely to discover the weakness.
Medium - An attacker might be able to discover the weakness.
High - It is very likely that an attacker can discover the weakness.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
None - An attacker has no chance of success.
Low - An attacker has very limited chances of success.
Medium - An attacker would probably target this weakness successfully.
High - It is highly likely that an attacker would target this weakness successfully.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Complete - The control is completely effective against the weakness.
Best-Available - The control follows best current practices.
Indirect (Defense-in-Depth) - The control does not specifically protect against exploitation of the weakness.
Moderate - The protection mechanism is commonly used but has known limitations that might be bypassed with some effort by a knowledgeable attacker.
Limited - There are simplistic methods or accidental restrictions that might prevent a casual attacker from exploiting the issue.
None - No controls exist.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
Limited - The weakness is encountered rarely, or never.
Common - The weakness is encountered periodically.
High - The weakness is encountered very often, but it is not widespread.
Widespread - The weakness is found in most or all software in the associated environment.
Default
Not Applicable - This factor is being intentionally ignored in the score calculation.
Unknown - There is not enough information to provide a value for this factor.
